title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act titled "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997" is also known as the "Short Title". It includes findings outlined in Section 2. Congress finds that private security officers in the United States are growing rapidly and function as an adjunct to public law enforcement by helping to reduce and prevent crime. The private security industry offers opportunities for entry-level job applicants, including those facing unemployment. These officers protect individuals, property, and proprietary information in various operations such as banks. Private security officers protect tangible and intangible property and proprietary information in diverse operations such as banks, hospitals, chemical companies, oil and gas refineries, airports, communication facilities, office complexes, schools, residential properties, apartment complexes, gated communities, and more. Sworn law enforcement officers provide significant services in public areas, supplemented by private security officers who offer prevention and reporting services in support of regular sworn police. The growth of private security services has increased rapidly as the number of public law enforcement officers has decreased. Private security officers are more likely to interact with the public due to the rise of large shopping malls replacing public shopping streets. They provide prevention and reporting services in support of, but not in place of, regular sworn police. The growth of private security services has accelerated as the number of public law enforcement officers has decreased. This growth aims to provide more law enforcement officers to combat serious crimes. The public struggles to differentiate between sworn officers and private security personnel. The American public demands qualified and well-trained private security personnel. The American public demands qualified, well-trained private security personnel as an adjunct to sworn law enforcement officers. Private security officers should undergo thorough screening, especially since many carry weapons. SEC. 3. BACKGROUND CHECKS. Background checks for private security officers require submission of fingerprints or other identification methods to the Attorney General for a background check. Employers can seek authorization from employees for this process, and the Attorney General will search the National Crime Information Index. The Attorney General conducts background checks for private security officers by searching the National Crime Information Index and providing identification and criminal history records within 30 days. The use of advanced technology is encouraged for compiling criminal history information. Associations must submit employee fingerprints for identification. An association designated under this section must submit employee fingerprints to the Attorney General for identification within one business day. They are also required to transfer identification and criminal history records to the employer promptly. Additionally, the association must provide copies of requests made on behalf of employers to licensing authorities or regulatory agencies in the respective states. The association designated under this section must submit employee fingerprints to the Attorney General for identification and criminal history records. The Attorney General may prescribe regulations for security, confidentiality, accuracy, and audits. A report to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary is required two years after enactment. The association must submit employee fingerprints for identification and criminal history records. The Attorney General will report to Congress on the number of inquiries made by employers under this section after 2 years. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends section 534 of title 28, US Code to include private security officer background check associations designated by the Attorney General.

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY. Imposes fines or imprisonment for misuse of information obtained under section 3 for private security officer employment purposes.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. Employers relying on criminal history information provided by the Attorney General for employment decisions are not liable for damages. In this Act, the term "Attorney General" includes any designated person or entity, such as the FBI. The term "employee" includes job applicants. The term "employer" refers to a person providing services of private security officers as an independent contractor, licensed or certified by one or more states. The term "fingerprint" in the context of private security services includes any approved method of positive identification. A private security officer is an individual who provides security services, whether armed or unarmed, as an independent contractor or employee. A private security officer is an individual, whether armed or unarmed, who provides security services as an independent contractor or employee. This does not include sworn police officers with law enforcement powers, licensed professionals, employees in internal audit or credit functions, or those with incidental duties. Employees excluded from the definition of private security officers include those in internal audit or credit functions, individuals on active duty in the military service, employees of electronic security system companies, employees involved in the secure movement of prisoners, and employees of armored vehicle companies. The term "security services" includes observing/reporting intrusion, theft, unlawful activity, and protecting individuals/property. The term "security services" encompass the observation or reporting of unlawful activity, protection of individuals or property, control of access to premises, maintenance of order and safety at public activities, and provision of canine services for protection or detection of unlawful substances. The term "State" refers to various regions including States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. The Attorney General may collect user fees for requests for criminal history information. The effective date of this Act is July 1, 1999.
